üìë Financial Statements and Key Metrics

financial-statements metrics accounting

2.1 Why is Tesla's P/E Ratio Much Higher Than Apple's?

üìå The Reasons

  • Apple (AAPL)Ôºö
    • Mature company with slowing growth but stable profits.
    • P/E ratio typically ranges between 25‚Äì30.
  • Tesla (TSLA)Ôºö
    • High-growth company with high investor expectations for the future.
    • Even with modest profits, the market gives it a very high P/E multiple (40‚Äì60+) because investors believe it will expand rapidly in the future.

üëâ SummaryÔºö

High P/E ‚â† the company is necessarily more profitable, but rather the market is willing to pay a higher premium for "future growth".

2.2 The Three Major Financial Statements: The Company's "Health Report"

How to Quickly Read a Public Company's Financial Report in 5 Minutes?

üìä Income Statement

Understanding a Public Company's Income Statement in 2 Minutes

  • Shows: how much money the company made during a specific period.
  • Main structure:
    1. Revenue
    2. Gross Profit (Revenue ‚Äì Cost)
    3. Operating Income
    4. Operating Expenses
    5. Net Income

üìå Gross Profit Margin

  • FormulaÔºö
  • Gross Profit = Revenue ‚Äì Cost of Goods Sold (e.g., production costs, material costs).
  • SignificanceÔºö
    • Measures the profitability of the product itself.
    • High gross margin ‚Üí the product has pricing power, indicating strong brand or technological moat.
  • ExamplesÔºö
    • Apple (iPhone): Gross margin ~43%
    • Costco: Gross margin ~12%, but wins through scale

üìå Net Profit Margin

  • FormulaÔºö
  • Net Profit = Gross Profit ‚Äì Operating Expenses ‚Äì Financial Expenses ‚Äì Taxes.
  • SignificanceÔºö
    • Measures how much money the company can ultimately retain.
    • High net margin ‚Üí good cost control, healthier business model.
  • ExamplesÔºö
    • Microsoft: Net margin ~30% (low marginal cost for software)
    • Walmart: Net margin ~2‚Äì3% (intense competition in retail)

‚ùå Common Misconceptions

  • Misconception 1: Higher gross margin = the company must be more profitable.
    • Example: Luxury companies have high gross margins, but may have low net profits due to high advertising and R&D expenses.
  • Misconception 2: Low net margin = bad company.
    • Example: Walmart's net margin is only 2‚Äì3%, but due to its massive scale, it's still one of the world's most profitable retail companies.

‚úÖ Correct Understanding

  • Gross Margin: Reflects the "per-unit profitability" of products, indicating whether the company has pricing power.
  • Net Margin: Reflects how much money the company "ultimately retains", indicating management and cost control levels.
  • Investment Logic: You need to look at both gross margin and net margin together to judge the true quality of a company's profitability.

üíµ Cash Flow Statement

One Video to Understand Corporate Cash Flow Statement
Understanding Cash Flow Statement in 3 Minutes

üìå Definition

  • The Cash Flow Statement reflects the company's cash receipts and payments during a specific period.
  • It answers the question:
    • Is the money the company earned real cash?
    • Or just "paper profits"?

üëâ Analogy: The Income Statement is like a "report card", while the Cash Flow Statement is a "bank statement". The report card can look good, but the bank balance is what matters.

üìä Three Main Components

1Ô∏è‚É£ Operating Cash Flow (OCF)

  • Source: Cash generated from core business operations.
  • Formula (simplified): Operating Cash Flow = Net Income + Non-cash Expenses (e.g., depreciation) + Changes in Working Capital
  • Significance: Measures whether the core business is "generating cash".
  • ExamplesÔºö
    • Apple: Operating cash flow ~ $110 billion/year ‚Üí very healthy.
    • Some startups: Net income is positive, but OCF is negative ‚Üí can't collect cash, relying on credit.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Investing Cash Flow (ICF)

  • Source: Investment, acquisition, and asset disposal activities.
  • Formula (simplified): Investing Cash Flow = Cash Inflow from Investment Recovery ‚àí Capital Expenditure
  • Significance: Reflects the company's investment in expansion, M&A, and R&D.
  • ExamplesÔºö
    • Tesla: Invests heavily in building Gigafactories each year ‚Üí investing cash flow is usually negative.
    • TSMC: Massive capital expenditure (CapEx) ‚Üí investing cash flow is negative long-term, but future capacity increases.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Financing Cash Flow (FCF)

  • Source: Company financing and dividends.
  • Formula (simplified): Financing Cash Flow = Borrowing + Stock Issuance ‚àí Debt Repayment ‚àí Dividends
  • Significance: Shows whether the company relies on "borrowing" to survive.
  • ExamplesÔºö
    • SoFi: Continuously raised funds in early stages (cash inflow), but as business stabilizes, gradually relies on its own cash flow.
    • Coca-Cola: Stable long-term dividends ‚Üí financing cash flow is often negative.

üìå Free Cash Flow (FCF)

  • Formula: Free Cash Flow = Operating Cash Flow ‚àí Capital Expenditure
  • SignificanceÔºö
    • The cash the company can "freely use".
    • Investors pay special attention ‚Üí because this is the real cash that can be used for dividends, buybacks, and reinvestment.
  • ExamplesÔºö
    • Apple: Free cash flow $100 billion ‚Üí enough for dividends + stock buybacks.
    • Netflix: Had negative free cash flow for a long time due to investment in original content, but later turned positive.

‚ö†Ô∏è Common Misconceptions

  1. Misconception 1: Positive net income = cash flow must be good
    • ‚ùå Wrong: Some companies use "accounting tricks" to make profits look good, but actually can't collect cash.
    • Example: Some real estate companies show paper profits, but cash flow is negative long-term.
  2. Misconception 2: Negative investing cash flow = bad company
    • ‚ùå Wrong: Many growth companies in expansion phase have negative investing cash flow, which is actually good (shows they're building factories/R&D).
  3. Misconception 3: Positive financing cash flow = healthy
    • ‚ùå Wrong: Some companies rely on debt to maintain operations, which actually increases risk.

‚úÖ Correct Understanding

  • Priority order for cash flowÔºö
    • Operating Cash Flow > 0 = healthy core business.
    • Investing Cash Flow < 0 = investing in the future.
    • Free Cash Flow > 0 = can really give money to shareholders.
  • Investment LogicÔºö
    • If a company has high profits but poor cash flow ‚Üí be careful.
    • If a company has low profits but strong cash flow ‚Üí the model may be more stable.

üìò Balance Sheet

üìå Definition

  • Balance Sheet = a snapshot of the company's financial position at a specific point in time.
  • It answers the questions:
    • What "assets" does the company have now? (Assets)
    • How much debt does it owe? (Liabilities)
    • How much do shareholders actually own? (Shareholders' Equity)

üëâ Analogy: The Income Statement is like a "report card" (performance over a period), while the Balance Sheet is a "bankbook + IOUs" (the company's real financial position today).

üìä Structure

1Ô∏è‚É£ Assets

Resources owned by the company, can be divided into:

  • Current Assets (can be converted to cash within one year): Cash, Accounts Receivable, Inventory
  • Non-current Assets (held long-term): Plant, Equipment, Patents, Long-term Investments

2Ô∏è‚É£ Liabilities

Money owed to others, obligations to repay:

  • Current Liabilities (due within one year): Accounts Payable, Short-term Debt
  • Long-term Liabilities (due after one year): Long-term Loans, Bonds

3Ô∏è‚É£ Shareholders' Equity

Company's "net worth" ‚Üí shareholders' true share.

üëâ Simple understanding:

  • You buy a house worth $1 million (asset), take a loan of $700,000 (liability), and you put in $300,000 yourself (shareholders' equity).

üìå Important Formulas

Accounting Equation

This is the fundamental law of accounting, always true.

Debt Ratio

  • Measures the company's leverage level.
  • High ‚Üí high risk; Low ‚Üí stable.

Current Ratio

  • Measures the company's short-term debt-paying ability.
  • 1 ‚Üí theoretically can pay off short-term debt.

Quick Ratio

  • A stricter short-term debt-paying indicator (because inventory may not be sellable).

üìå Case Studies

üçè Apple (2023)

  • Total Assets: $352 billion
  • Total Liabilities: $294 billion
  • Shareholders' Equity: $58 billion
  • Debt Ratio: ‚âà 83%
  • Conclusion: Apple has significant debt, but strong cash flow can fully cover it.

üöó Tesla (2023)

  • Total Assets: $105 billion
  • Total Liabilities: $36 billion
  • Shareholders' Equity: $69 billion
  • Debt Ratio: ‚âà 34%
  • Conclusion: Tesla has relatively low debt, expansion relies more on equity financing.

üè¶ Ping An of China (A-share financial company)

  • Characteristic: Financial companies generally have high debt ratios (banks and insurance companies essentially "borrow short and lend long").
  • Debt ratio > 90%, but this is an industry characteristic.

‚ö†Ô∏è Common Misconceptions

  1. Misconception 1: High debt ratio = dangerous company
    • ‚ùå Wrong: Some industries are naturally high-debt (banks, real estate), which doesn't mean unhealthy.
    • Correct: Need to consider cash flow and industry characteristics.
  2. Misconception 2: Small shareholders' equity = company is worthless
    • ‚ùå Wrong: Light-asset companies (like Google, Meta) have valuable brands and data, but assets aren't significant on the balance sheet.
  3. Misconception 3: Higher current ratio is always better
    • ‚ùå Wrong: Too high may indicate the company has too much idle cash, low efficiency.

‚úÖ Correct Understanding

  • Debt is not bad: Reasonable debt can amplify returns.
  • Look at structure: Short-term debt vs long-term debt, which has a higher proportion?
  • Combine the three statementsÔºö
    • Income Statement tells you if it's profitable.
    • Cash Flow Statement tells you if money is coming in.
    • Balance Sheet tells you if the foundation is stable.

üéØ Classroom Activity

  1. Open Yahoo Finance ‚Üí search AAPL (Apple).
    • Find the Balance Sheet.
    • Calculate: Debt Ratio, Current Ratio.
  2. Think: Why does Apple have high debt, but the market still confidently buys its stock?

üìò Summary

  • Balance Sheet = snapshot of company health.
  • Three core indicators: Debt Ratio, Current Ratio, Quick Ratio.
  • Investment should consider industry characteristics, don't mechanically look at numbers.
  • An excellent company is often not "debt-free", but "uses debt in the right places".
  • Reflects: what the company owns (assets), what it owes (liabilities), and what belongs to shareholders (shareholders' equity).

2.3 Relationships Between the Three Statements

  • The "Net Income" from the Income Statement flows into the "Operating Cash Flow" of the Cash Flow Statement.
  • The "Capital Expenditure" in the Cash Flow Statement affects "Fixed Assets" in the Balance Sheet.
  • The "Shareholders' Equity" in the Balance Sheet corresponds to "Retained Earnings" from the Income Statement.

üëâ Simple understandingÔºö

  • Income Statement = company's profit report card
  • Cash Flow Statement = whether money actually came in
  • Balance Sheet = how much "assets" the company has now

2.4 Case Studies

üçè Apple (2023 Financial Report Simplified)

  • Revenue: $383 billion
  • Gross Margin: 43%
  • Net Margin: 25%
  • Free Cash Flow: $100+ billion
  • Conclusion: High profits + strong cash flow ‚Üí "cash machine".

üöó Tesla (2023 Financial Report Simplified)

  • Revenue: $96.1 billion
  • Gross Margin: 25% (lower than Apple)
  • Net Margin: 11%
  • Free Cash Flow: $9 billion
  • Conclusion: Profit margin lower than Apple, but fast growth rate ‚Üí market gives higher valuation.
